Models

We develop a linear regression model for each plot using the lm() function built into R. We then find Pearson’s correlation coefficient to measure the strength of the relationship between our variables of interest.

\(y_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1X_i + \epsilon_i\)


Call:
lm(formula = rank2021 ~ score, data = mergedData)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-29.939 -11.376  -3.007  11.082  30.579 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) 128.6747    16.1218   7.981 1.06e-10 ***
score        -0.2128     0.0349  -6.098 1.19e-07 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 15 on 54 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.4078,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.3968 
F-statistic: 37.19 on 1 and 54 DF,  p-value: 1.187e-07

Call:
lm(formula = rank2021 ~ iq, data = mergedData)
